content: Definitely a valid concern — I’m not a member of the TypeScript team, but my impression is that compatibility with JavaScript is now the higher priority of the two. I think it’s also worth noting the beginning of the Design Goals document you’re referencing: This document serves to outline the general design principles we have based the TypeScript language on. While it is by no means exhaustive, it aims to summarize the rules by which we’ve made many of the decisions that have shaped the language. Some of these rules are subjective, and at times are at odds with each other; reaching the right balance and making the right exceptions is the essence of how successful programming languages are designed. (Bold added by me.) It looks like the TypeScript team recognizes the issue you raise. As TypeScript has continued to evolve, the TypeScript team seems to be focusing more and more on JavaScript compatibility, and they’re not afraid to break past versions of TypeScript: TypeScript Breaking Changes
